Module io.jstach.opt.spring.example
Package io.jstach.opt.spring.example.hello

Class HelloController

java.lang.Object
io.jstach.opt.spring.example.hello.HelloController
@Controller public class HelloController extends Object
Example hello world controller using different ways to use JStachio for web development.
Author:
agentgt

  • Field Summary

    Fields
    Modifier and Type
    Field
    Description
    Template<HelloModel>
    view
    Spring will inject this as the templates are component scanned as this projects module io.jstach.opt.spring.example has a config that will add @ Component to all generated code.

    Modifier and Type
    Method
    Description
    ResponseEntity<HelloModel>
    entity()
    Here we use a ResponseEntity which allows use to set status codes with our model to be rendered.
    HelloModel
    hello()
    Here we use JStachio runtime to resolve the renderer (in this case we are calling them Views) via Springs Http Message Converter.
    View
    mvc()
    Here we use JStacheInterfaces to make our model implement a Spring View to support the traditional servlet MVC approach.
    TemplateModel
    templateModel()
    Here we use the generated code directly and return a TemplateModel which is analogous to ModelAndView.
    void
    wired(Writer writer)
    Here we use the wired renderer that does not have filtering and thus cannot use JMustache for dynamic editing of templates.

  • Field Details

    • view

      @Autowired(required=true) public Template<HelloModel> view
      Spring will inject this as the templates are component scanned as this projects module io.jstach.opt.spring.example has a config that will add @ Component to all generated code.

  • Constructor Details

    • HelloController

      public HelloController()
      Placate JDK 18 Javadoc

  • Method Details

    • hello

      @GetMapping("/") @ResponseBody public HelloModel hello()
      Here we use JStachio runtime to resolve the renderer (in this case we are calling them Views) via Springs Http Message Converter.
      Returns:
      the model that will be used to find the correct view and then rendered using that view
      See Also:
      • JStachioHttpMessageConverter
      API Note
      Notice that the method has to be annotated with @ResponseBody.

    • templateModel

      @GetMapping("/templateModel") @ResponseBody public TemplateModel templateModel()
      Here we use the generated code directly and return a TemplateModel which is analogous to ModelAndView.
      Returns:
      the template model pair that already has the template found.
      See Also:
      • JStachioHttpMessageConverter
      API Note
      Notice that the method has to be annotated with @ResponseBody.

    • entity

      @GetMapping("/responseEntity") public ResponseEntity<HelloModel> entity()
      Here we use a ResponseEntity which allows use to set status codes with our model to be rendered.
      Returns:
      a response entity.
      See Also:
      • JStachioHttpMessageConverter

    • mvc

      @GetMapping("/mvc") public View mvc()
      Here we use JStacheInterfaces to make our model implement a Spring View to support the traditional servlet MVC approach. The model will use the static jstachio singleton that will be the spring one.

      This approach has pros and cons. It makes your models slightly coupled to Spring MVC but allows you to return different views if say you had to redirect on some inputs (RedirectView).

      Returns:
      the model that will be used as View
      See Also:
      • JStachioHttpMessageConverter
      API Note
      Notice that the return type is View.

    • wired

      @GetMapping("/wired") public void wired(Writer writer) throws IOException
      Here we use the wired renderer that does not have filtering and thus cannot use JMustache for dynamic editing of templates.
      Parameters:
      writer - spring will inject the servlet output
      Throws:
      IOException - an error while writing to the output
